conclusion: Consider the electric field created by the two point charges at points M and N.
Point B is located at the center of the equilateral triangle formed by points M, N, and B.
The distance from B to M (or N) is L.
The electric field E due to a point charge Q at a distance r is given by E = kQ/r^2.
Calculate the electric field due to charge +Q at point M: E_M = kQ/L^2.
Calculate the electric field due to charge -Q at point N: E_N = kQ/L^2.
The electric field due to +Q at M points away from M.
The electric field due to -Q at N points towards N.
Since M and N form an equilateral triangle with B, the electric fields at B due to M and N are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction along the line MN.
Calculate the net electric field at B: E_net = E_M - E_N = 0.
The electric force F on a charge q in an electric field E is given by F = qE.
Since the net electric field at B is zero, F = q * 0 = 0.
The magnitude of the electric force experienced by the small ball when it reaches point B is 0.
